Here’s one I wrote shortly after George Floyd was killed :( The Lion’s Perspective By: Marco Anne At the zoo, you see lions, cranes, bears, tigers They’re all behind bars, In a cage, every day of their lives, And people, they stare or wave. Seeing the animals brings them such joy! But did you ever think to put yourself in the lion’s place? What does he see? How can he live the way he does? The lion, in that small, barred cell, Really does not see himself as being in a cage! The human beings are the animals, He observes them everyday as entertainment. But the humans’ enclosure, Something is peculiar about it. Yes. They are contrasting colours and Covered in complex clothing. But where are the fences? Nothing divides them, no physical bars, no walls, Just one open area. Free. We need to live like that lion sees. Our size, shape or colour doesn’t divide us. Neither do our abilities, disabilities or religion. We may seem different, but in the end, We’re all human. Nothing between us. Nothing blocking us from one another. Without boundaries. The way that lion sees us. That was for a free verse assignment but I re-worked it after the original submission because I realized that I didn’t really like it. (I got an A- lol) This next one was written when I was in grade 5. I don’t really like it but tell me what you think :) The Night Storm By: Marco Anne When the downpour started, it was not strong. It kissed my window and nothing seemed wrong. Then a rumble sent shivers down my spine. The sky’s stomach was hungry, and a pit formed in mine. It lashed and it crashed for hours on end, I prayed for a stop to this, that God would send. I couldn’t stop thinking ‘bout the horrible pain, The fear, the shivers From this terrible rain. And then, was it quiet? Had my prayers worked? I looked out my window and up my hopes jerked! The sky! It was blue with no booming flashes. I smiled and sighed All those fears had become ashes. Fearing those storms was a thing of the past. They were simply a blip, In our great world, so vast. (We had to write that one for our bible class, I got a B because the rhyme scheme had a problem apparently) Wings! Marco Anne If only I had wings! Wouldn’t that be nice! And while the icy evergreens whisper, I’d take a dip in the river of purity. Erase from my mind, the guilt and the anger, And no longer, I’d be an obscurity. Perch on the tallest treetops, And drink in the breathtaking landscapes. Dive to the deepest depths, and swing by the trees with the apes. I would fly with the birds To the farthest of places - even Nebraska! To the Bermuda Triangle, To Belgium and to Alaska. All day and all night, I would do what I please. Flap in the limitless night air, Or ride on the colourful breeze. Ah, if only I had wings! Young Amelia always questioned this. No, they said. Girls do housework, men get jobs. But aprons, pots, pans and mops were not for her. Watching the male pilots, Watching the male baseball players, Watching and longing. She would accomplish what some men could never do: They said she couldn’t do it, but she did. Pilot school was only the beginning… She loved the adventure. She was hooked! That greasy, tangy, grimy smell of peril drew her in. She didn’t stop! Her pilot’s license lead to so many honours, But so much prejudice, They told her to give up, They told her she would never be equal to men, She didn’t stop. She accomplished what some men could never do: They had said she couldn’t do it, but she did. She had encouraged women, Break the barriers, she said. Stand up, speak out, she said. Women WILL be recognized. After crossing the Atlantic herself in 1932, Some people became truly convinced. Maybe women could do it as well as men. Maybe women were equal, And she kept encouraging this recognition. She accomplished what men would never do: They said she couldn’t do it but she did. But then, in 1937, she disappeared. Gone was that advocate. Gone while circumnavigating the globe, Standing up for the women and breaking down barriers. If she hadn’t had stood up, only men would be pilots. Only men could do work. Though Amelia was lost at sea, was she really gone? No! Of course not. Her legacy lives. She revolutionized how women are seen. And they said she couldn’t do it, but she did. “There’s more to life than being a passenger." Occasionally, but I’m not that good at it… I’ve been trying to learn recently but I don’t have enough time to throw at this project to really become much better for now… I write poetry in moments of emotional turmoil. It is moments like these that I cannot simply state how I feel - even to myself. There is too much anger and passion and elation and excitement at times to simply casually describe what’s going on. In those moments I feel like screaming an impassioned rant, to let my emotions explode out my mouth. I am not naturally a writer. I’ve worked on my writing, but I am principally an orator. Speaking comes naturally to me. I was practically born to rant. So my poetry rarely sounds like writing and sounds more like transcribed rants. With a bit of editing these sometimes become more similar to standard written language and not oration, but I rarely care to do this. I do not write poetry for anyone to read it - even myself, really. I write to make sense of my thoughts. It is as I transcribe the rants that are locked in my head, as I let them trickle through my fingers onto my notebook or into my laptop, they take on their own form and become more clear than they were when they were in my head. This is cathartic and useful. Even for those of us educated in psychology it is hard to understand what goes on in our minds. Our souls are stormy and unpredictable. Having a medium of expression through which one can let his insides out is often very important for emotional health. I know that for me it is. Thanks for asking

Here's a poem I've written recently Broken Wings Those who were trapped Stopped her from leaving. Even so, her wings grew As her heart started beating. Their made up reasons, She believed them not. She longed for where the skies are pure And where rain stops. [And thus she fled] Her wings brought her far, But their curses caught up. As she soared through the clouds, Her wings were shot down. Feather by feather, they tore up her wings. For each hope she had, she felt the pain sting. “It was a curse”, they said For those who broke free. “It was God's wish”, they spouted. She was left there to bleed. The fallen angel, with her wings stolen, She can no longer fly and her heart was broken. “Was it a sin?”, she wondered “For us to break free” Was there ever a purpose For us to resist?

Yes, I indulge in writing poetry. Below is a poem I wrote titled Quietude  To Quietude. For sound travels more leisurely than light, Keenly gathering moss along the lush slope of time. And so, prolonged thunder follows the flash of lightning; And so, applause rings long after the stage is emptied. To Quietude. For sound travels more leisurely than light, Keenly gathering moss along the lush slope of time. For sound travels more leisurely than light, Keenly gathering moss along the lush slope of time. And so, there is a simple gratitude owed to solitude; And so, the unheard moments of character slip by whilst stringing the strains of victory in Quietude.

Yes, but I don’t ever sit down and go “I’m going to write a poem now”. Instead, for me, poetry is a conduit for expression. The words flow when the mood strikes. If the wave has not washed over me, letting the language present itself as if through supernatural intervention, then I won’t force it. I write poetry only when it flows naturally. Most importantly, I write it only for myself. Thus, I write poetry erratically. I have written multiple poems within a week at certain stages in my life but gone months without writing any in others. A lot of my poetry is negative (as those emotions often were more consuming) but some of it speaks of my moments of pure hope. Some is wistful as I reflected on my cusp into adulthood, some is absurd as I deconstructed the crazy world around me. Overall, whenever I feel like reflecting upon my personal journey, I reread my works and the story they tell. In that way, I suppose that my poetry is a record of the journey of my soul. I shan’t claim that my poetry is good. As mentioned above, I have not written it for others to assess nor judge, but rather as a insight into a snapshot of myself - a flawed capture of a time when emotion overwhelmed me. However, I shall share a sole example here. A poem that is one of my personal favourites. It no longer applies to me; that doesn’t mean I should merely forget the time when it did. But seriously, don’t we all write poetry in some form or another? Dark Skies In a perpetual darkened sky, What do a few clouds matter? The shade they cover, meaningless. The ground already shadowed. What does rain mean to a man In a world that's cold and wet? What is the sound of thunder, When cries of the heart left you deaf? Snow is no longer cold, To one whose heart is stone. Wind's bite cannot touch the man, Who has already been worn to bone. To me the world is nothing. It holds no power over me. Cause I already lost myself in the dark, Already lost my will to see. The light that always beckons, Out of reach, it taunts. Tis high time I abandoned hope. It only leads to naught. The weather cannot touch me. The storms live in my heart. No matter what the world does to me. No more can I be hurt... -Daydreamer 25/06/2015

I have to be different here. I do not write poetry and I don't really enjoy poetry. Until recently the closest I came was fiddling with the random words on the refrigerator “magnetic poetry” until I found a fun app for iPad and iPhone. The app is called Creative Writer and it's similar to magnetic poetry. It's also similar to the predictive text on your device. There are several in-app purchase word sets but even the basic one is fun. Your keyboard is replaced with a long list of random words. Tap one that appeals to you. Then you have an all new set of words to choose your second word. And so on. But it's not random. The brain stimulator here is that you don't have to just ponder the right word; there are so many choices that you'll end up choosing a word that you wouldn't have thought of on your own but because you see it in the massive list your eyes are drawn to it. Despite my general disdain for poetry I find it relaxing and stimulating and when I return to my novel I feel the words flow more freely. I even think I may have created a couple decent poems using this app. There are also wordsets that are designed for prose. I write poetry often as well and find I now have enough poems to make up an entire anthology - an entire book of just my poetry. I only write poetry some of the time and only when a certain mood hits me. Its usually in moments of quiet contemplation alone and just after something has triggered me emotionally - a death - a world event - injustice, etc. Most of my poetry is dark - but much of it has a silver lining of hope at the end. Most of my poems are fairly short. I have only written a couple of lengthy ones. I will share a few examples. This first one was only written a night ago. HARBINGER: By Aaron R. I started the #5MinutePoetry movement, which encourages re-phrasing your Facebook statuses as poems that you spend 5–10 minutes crafting, the goal of which is to make Facebook a more interesting place for everyone. Here’s one of my favourites:  I dreamt I was a knight in armour  Riding over fields of crimson wheat, And with each step, recalled the farmer Lying, vanquished, in the furrows at my feet. Who was this man who’d sacrificed his life? What agency stepped in to lift my hand?  Did he have livestock? Children? Wife?  For whom he’d vivified once-barren land?  I dreamt I was a man of courage, Striving to accomplish noble deeds. The road ahead all but discouraged Cultivating any sort of seed. But looking down, I saw a man  Who’d put aside all pretenses of fame, And working quietly with plow and hand  Ensured that not a soul would know his name.  What good had all his effort brought to pass? How full had been the life that he had led? Was he content? Resigned? Steadfast? I’ll never know; I left him lying dead.   I dreamt my fate would carry me afar, But, waking, I am left with bitter dread. Was I truly meant to chase a shooting star? Or has my future’s joy already fled?   If so, oh well. I guess it’s back to bed.  Edit: Naman Agrawal has requested more! So, I’m including a couple short ones, and a longer piece. Hope you enjoy. We said once we'd stay friends forever;  Friends, whichever way our roads may lead.  Indeed, we said we'd find each other  If the other ever was in need.   But promises can't read the future's mind And kindness cannot walk the streets alone.  We've sown the seeds of discord with each step,  Which kept us both from reaching for the phone.   I do not question why our ties unwound.  I've found that second-guessing is a waste.  We faced our own distinct and sep'rate ways,  Each gazing toward a fate we can't outpace.   So here it is, my dear, my last adieu: A few sad lines I know you'll never read.  I concede to you all visions of a "someday" So that, one day, I'll from memory be freed.  Another emo poem: Tonight, there's something in the rain: Not really sorrow, not quite pain,  Just a whisper to convince my soggy brain there's no tomorrow;  That the trains I've wrecked  Left stains I've kept  Concealed through the years,  Now revealed through these tears wept by the sky.  Looking up, I find the raindrops start to fill my hooded eyes.  For I can't forget regret,  And I'll forever wonder "why?"  And now, getting political (February 6th, 2016)… Maybe he IS  Just a feel-good, yes-we-candidate, Pledging to withstand the state-run mandate That immigrants, blacks, and all working-class mothers Must forage for scraps  And/or wrestle each other Before they're allowed to live life like the rest of us,  Standing abreast of us,  Owning the rights that our forefathers left for us.  Is that ENOUGH for us? HuffPo seems to think so.   But when the going gets tough,  Seems the "tough" like to throw rowers overboard,  Hoping that "lightening the oars"  Might afford them a little more time with their families.  Why's is so hard to see why that's INSANITY?! Fuck off with your vanity,  Shut off Sean Hannity,  And once in a while recall your HUMANITY! Please! Can we All just Stop and  THINK?   I feel that we're nearing the brink of disaster,  And our options are "sink"  Or to row that must FASTER, So when some bastard tells you that "shrinking the ship" Is the ONE WAY to make sure our kids are equipped To avoid dereliction and "skip this shit, quick", Spend a thought to consider the kids who he'll KICK. And then ask how he's planning to keep us afloat When our boat consists only of thrones for the Kochs Bobbing lonely amidst democratic hypocri-sea.  Faced with that prospect, WHY CAN'T WE AGREE That The Land of the Free's not defined by its borders! That "Iraq" and "Iran" aren't new slang for "Mordor"; That in order for personal freedoms to thrive It's important each person can be KEPT ALIVE.  Doesn't mean much if "freedom" means "freedom to die."  So sure. Go ahead and despise the word "socialist." I couldn't care less, just so long as you'll toast to this: We've got this one shot to stop treading water.  Let's not fuck it up for our sons and daughters!

Eglantine Beams of light shine as different upon each soul as water flowsFor water always a smooth way it takes, and light only pure hearts it strikesHer heart was with joy filled, mine was with regretThe scent of morning air was fragrant in her room, air in my presence didn’t seem to existThe sun is bright, all glorious, all exalting except for a tortured mind in aloofness deep it resides I walked upon the hill with wistful eyes, for walking was still no lax I wandered and sang and cried, and momentary promises I no longer madeI took the pain and embraced it, and with my life swore to keep itNo more hiding, no more denying, the tragedy of a man is his rebirthWith broken but authentic soul I walked back, and to my past I now looked with peaceful assentFor each man kills the thing he loves, yet each man does not die She sat across the room, reading the books to which she was inuredShe was pristine indeed, and there was a shining quality to her eyesShe was quiet indeed, and there was soft wisdom to her wordsShe was perfect indeedBut no perfect thing had in jollity lived before, for perfection to man was not madeHer eyes in their glances were as wistful as mineAnd her soul was equally with loneliness melted as with purityMore she wanted and much more she didn’t getAnd to a giant’s eyes as sad as I am she looked if not sadderFor a virtuous heart’s sadness is more tragic than the tragedy of vicious man. Sight is the only gift worth having and nature has a smell of its ownTo which the skin reacts as strong as the heart beatsIn my way back from where I brought healing to the depth of my breath And within the pacific nature of my post satisfaction perplexity I saw itIt was of ineffable beauty and elusive appealJ’ai vu une églantine to which my composition has shown no immunityTo which every part of my body has shown desperate longingTo which I presented my hand, with shyness, with hesitance, with trembling fingersTo which I instantly lost myself, for such creature was surely made to dominate with overwhelming energyIt didn’t disappoint, and with conspicuous consent it presented itselfAlmost as if it knew in my undeserving hand for not so long it will reside My walk became my journey for your journey defines your life beyond your daysA journey of extravagant joy and sadness, of melancholy, of sleepless nights, but colorful daysAnd as every pair of eyes that touches the sacred stone of love, both our eyes were no longer wistful, not foreverNot since the morning where with a smiling face I handed it to herIn that morning I said, with a trembling voice and tearing eyes: "Ma précieuse églantine est la tienne".

Published by Wordfest Print Anthology 2016 Selected for the Waco Cultural Arts Festival Where the Woods Open There's a path I always take, down to the river where the woods are dressed down, open The light of the sky doesn't shine, in your eyes but leads the way to redemption I like to stand there for a moment, on the shortcut created by troubled feet woven with wilderness bliss, and cigarettes butts It's a path that never sleeps I see the same semi-blind vision, of the river every time. I hear baby boat horns blaring in the distance, and floating out of view I walk to the rhythm of the trees, the faint sound of"Wild Thing" playing in the car. I carry a bent black rod with a tangled neon line ,a mud covered box of rusty hooks and flaming red bobbers I wear my T-Shirt that says "Iron City Beer" that's cut off at the belly or sometimes my other one that says "Just Do It" with shredded denim shorts that ride my buttocks After a few seconds of inhaling and exhaling an indecision, I do what most fisher men do, with only my thoughts to keep me company I find a clean rock and cast with desperation The woods close. —————————————- Poem #2 Published by Blue Hole Print Magazine 2016 selected for the Georgetown Festival The Outsider The less I speak when I am pushed to fall skinless into the brooding sun beam My bright voice falls spiritless on its tongue the skirt of it tears and tears and seems unsure of its reflection It seems to rise up into the suns mouth and turn there to a muffled sigh Slowly it begins to purposely let itself go you see, nothing of the air can seem to stroke it without breaking it, upward and away and right when it's just about ready to lose its sensitivity to the salty wind it sees your face as salvation the heart of it burst open, it sees the ground as a giant god like fresh dirt, it meets the ground gladly and gladly, and gladly. Quiet Bravery It was a night in March of ’89. We slept in our beds, everything fine. Not time to get up; I suddenly awoke. There was a definite smell of smoke! My husband ran out ahead of me. He’s learned at the Naval Academy: Find the fire; put it out fast. Come back, I said, You ran right past! The lights didn’t work; where was the door? Just when I couldn’t breathe anymore, My hand touched the doorknob as I sank to the floor. I ran down the hallway to find my son. Aaron, where are you? Are you okay, hon? Sleeping like a baby, I picked up my child. Tripping over furniture-it was all so wild! I ran next-door, dialed 911, terrified…My house is on fire, my husband’s inside! I ran back to my house, and my heart soared. Richard was waiting. Out the window, smoke poured. For months I would live with a great sense of fear, Finally subsiding after one solid year. The firemen’s quiet bravery, their looks of concern is what helped me after sparks started to burn. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~Jane Lee Holmes Seattle WA U.S.A. International Who’s Who in Poetry 2012

A great way to write poetry for beginners is to imagine you’re not writing poetry at all. Too often we get caught up in cliche ideas of what poetry needs to be (roses are red, violets are blue, etc) and we don’t just put our heart into our work. Instead try this: write a brief story of something important to you, like an event or a feeling. Now try to make most of the lines you wrote very descriptive and unique (instead of saying, “I went to the store afterward”, say, “Lines of retail bricks and mortar sucked me in, moth to a flame.”). You’ll end up with a poem you actually like, rather than something you contorted yourself and your writing to create by trying to make it rhyme, etc.
